Award.AwardTitle: Exploring New Frontiers in Flavor Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Particle physics seeks to understand the laws governing the universe at the most fundamental level. There are indications that our current best formulation of these laws, the Standard Model, is still incomplete. A promising route to the discovery of physics beyond the Standard Model is the precision study of decays of so-called bottom quarks -- elementary particles similar to but much heavier than the up and down quarks found inside protons and neutrons. In this project, the properties of several types of bottom quark decays will be calculated. This involves solving the equations of quantum chromodynamics on a space-time lattice using supercomputers. The results of these calculations can be compared to experimental data from the Large Hadron Collider and the future SuperKEKB Collider to search for signs of new fundamental physics. This project will provide training to students at the University of Arizona not only in particle physics, but also in data analysis and in supercomputing.

Lattice QCD computations will be performed for selected decays of bottom hadrons that have a high potential for the discovery of new physics, and whose theoretical description requires ab-initio determinations of new types of hadronic matrix elements. The research will focus on the following three areas: (1) Decays of bottom baryons, (2) Decays of bottom hadrons with multi-hadron final states, and (3) Long-distance contributions to flavor-changing neutral-current decays. This project will help understand recent hints for deviations from the Standard Model, observed by the LHCb experiment in rare decays of B mesons. It will also address an important puzzle concerning the smallest element of the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa quark mixing matrix.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our current understanding of fundamental particle physics, the Standard Model, is still incomplete. The Standard Model leaves many questions unanswered, such as: What are the constituents of dark matter? What is the reason for the observed hierarchies in the masses and coupling strengths of the elementary particles?

A promising way of searching for physics beyond the Standard Model with particle collider experiments is the precision study of processes in which quarks change from one type to another. Such processes may receive observable quantum corrections from new interactions that so far have escaped direct detection. Recent measurements of decay processes in which a heavy bottom quark changes to a lighter type of quark have in fact revealed some tantalizing deviations from Standard-Model predictions.

Making reliable Standard-Model predictions for decays of this kind is challenging because quarks interact strongly with gluons and are bound inside hadrons. The effects of these strong interactions can be calculated from first principles only in lattice quantum chromodynamics (lattice QCD), a numerical method requiring supercomputers.

Traditionally, lattice QCD studies of decays of heavy quarks have focused on processes with mesons, which are bound states of one quark and one antiquark. Furthermore, it was not possible to correctly treat cases in which more than one meson is produced in the decay process. In this project, lattice QCD calculations were performed for decays of baryons, which are bound state of three quarks, and for decays with two mesons in the final state. The calculations for baryons have enabled the first determination of |Vub|, the fundamental parameters of the Standard Model that describes the coupling strength between bottom and up quarks, at the Large Hadron Collider. This analysis placed strong constraints on possible new interactions involving the right-handed chirality component of the quarks (in the Standard Model, the weak force couples only to the left-handed component). Calculations were also performed for decays involving the transition of a bottom quark to a strange quark and two muons; for this rare type of transition, measurements with mesons are currently in tension with the Standard Model. In this project, precise predictions were obtained for a baryonic decay of this type, and calculations for important decays with two mesons in the final state were initiated. Two types of decays of charm baryons were also computed for the first time in lattice QCD, and the results were found to be in agreement with recent measurements performed by the BESIII and LHCb Collaborations.
